author: By Marc Tracy
title: The Times hits its goal of 10 million subscriptions with the addition of The Athletic.
description: The deal for the sports site, which was completed on Tuesday, helped the company reach that goal a couple of years early.
content: The New York Times Company reached its goal of 10 million subscriptions ahead of schedule, the company said Wednesday, aided substantially by the 1.2 million it gained by buying the sports news website The Athletic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: A jump in European inflation adds pressure on the E.C.B. to act.
description: Inflation in the eurozone set its latest record, climbing to 5.1 percent in January, amid persistently high energy costs and tensions over Ukraine.
content: The eurozone started 2022 much as it ended the previous year, with record-setting inflation that defied expectations. Now economists are wondering if the persistently high prices could pressure the European Central Bank to change its position that the situation is temporary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: A Brand-New Cake From a Pastry Paradise
description: Paris’s Left Bank is brimming with sweets, including the financiers that inspired this elegant and easygoing dessert.
content: For the past 25 years, my husband, Michael, and I have lived in Saint-Germain-des-​Prés, the neighborhood on Paris’s Left Bank that I read about as a teenager. It was home to two of the city’s most famous literary cafes: Les Deux Magots, where a picture of Ernest Hemingway and The New Yorker Paris correspondent Janet Flanner hung behind my favorite table against the back wall, and Café de Flore, which had often doubled as Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre’s living room. There were bookstores that stayed open until midnight and cafe terraces crowded with people well past then. The Rue de Seine, now lined with restaurants, was a busy market street with many storefronts open to the sidewalk. There was a fish market and a butcher shop with sawdust on the floor, vegetable stands and a fromagerie. Around the corner, on Rue de Buci, there was a flower shop, and Michael thought it could have doubled as the setting for “An American in Paris.” Gene Kelly, who danced his way through that movie, never appeared, but we spotted Catherine Deneuve many times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: U.S. broadcast coverage includes curling and hockey.
description: Programming starts with mixed doubles in curling and with women’s teams on the hockey rink.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Wednesday night with hockey, curling and Alpine skiing. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: How Democrats Can Stop a Red Wave
description: Republicans like their chances in November. But politics can change quickly.
content: A “red wave” is building this year — or so we’re told.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Novak
title: A Music Museum Opens in the Heart of Hungary’s Culture Wars
description: At City Park in Budapest, a building project has come to exemplify the politics of Viktor Orban, the country’s far-right prime minister.
content: BUDAPEST — A polarizing project by the government of Viktor Orban, Hungary’s far-right prime minister, to transform the historic City Park here into a museum district has produced its first building: the House of Music, Hungary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Let the Games begin (early): The U.S. and China win as curling gets things started.
description: China surprised Switzerland in mixed doubles as competition began a full 48 hours before the opening ceremony.
content: With some of the greatest athletes of the world assembled in Beijing, the sporting competition opened Wednesday with a rock sliding down some ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
title: Over a Million Flee as Afghanistan’s Economy Collapses
description: Thousands of Afghans are trying to sneak into Iran and Pakistan each day, as incomes have dried up and life-threatening hunger has become widespread.
content: ZARANJ, Afghanistan — From their hide-out in the desert ravine, the migrants could just make out the white lights of the Iranian border glaring over the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: How Spiking Energy Prices Complicate the Fight Against Global Warming
description: Oil and gas prices are soaring, while coal use is reaching record highs worldwide. Here’s what the upheaval could mean for climate policies across the globe.
content: WASHINGTON — While world leaders have vowed to scale back the use of fossil fuels to help keep a lid on global warming, a drastic upheaval in the markets for oil, natural gas and coal could complicate the shift toward cleaner sources of energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jacob’s Pillow Announces Lineup for 2022 Season
description: The influential dance festival is returning to its indoor theater after the pandemic complicated the last two seasons.
content: After two years of cancellations and weather-dependent outdoor performances, the Jacob’s Pillow dance festival is making its return to the theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $700,000 Homes in Texas, Oregon and North Carolina
description: A Tudor Revival house in Dallas, an 1896 Victorian in Portland and a post-and-beam cottage in Fairview.
content: This house is in the M Streets neighborhood, named for its concentration of streets beginning with the letter M and beloved for its 1920s and 1930s Tudor Revival homes. Knox Street is about a mile away, with an Apple store, a number of upscale furniture and housewares stores, and restaurants serving New American, French and Mediterranean food. Glencoe Park, which has basketball courts and open green space, is a few blocks north; Southern Methodist University is about five minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Giulia Heyward
title: What It’s Like to Be a Black Student at an Elite Boarding School
description: We spoke with Kendra James, the author of “Admissions: A Memoir of Surviving Boarding School.”
content: When some people meet Kendra James, they have a hard time believing she really went to boarding school. She was a rarity: In 2003, James became the first Black legacy student at the Taft School, an elite preparatory academy in Connecticut. And in “Admissions: A Memoir of Surviving Boarding School,” James gives readers a firsthand account of what it was like to stick out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Danai Gurira Will Star as Richard III at Shakespeare in the Park
description: The actress, known for “The Walking Dead” and “Black Panther,” will headline a return to semi-normal for the annual festival, which will also present “As You Like It.”
content: The Public Theater, anticipating a semi-normal summer this year, is planning two full-scale productions for Free Shakespeare in the Park, including a run of “Richard III” starring Danai Gurira in the title role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: With Commanders, the Washington N.F.L. Franchise Moves Past Old Name
description: After a two-year search, the team announced a new name and mascot to replace the generic moniker it adopted to replace the longtime name, which was considered a racial slur of Native Americans.
content: Washington, meet the Commanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Maggie Haberman, Alan Feuer and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Jan. 6 Panel Examining Trump’s Role in Proposals to Seize Voting Machines
description: The House committee is looking into efforts by the former president’s outside advisers to create a legal basis for national security agencies to help reverse his defeat in 2020.
content: WASHINGTON — The House Jan. 6 committee is scrutinizing former President Donald J. Trump’s involvement in proposals to seize voting machines after the 2020 election, including efforts to create a legal basis for directing national security agencies to take such an extreme action, according to three people with knowledge of the committee’s activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Troy Closson
title: 4 Are Charged in Overdose Death of Michael K. Williams
description: Security video helped investigators piece together the sale of the fatal dose to Mr. Williams, best known for his role on “The Wire,” according to court records.
content: A Brooklyn man was charged on Wednesday with selling a deadly dose of fentanyl-laced heroin to the actor Michael K. Williams, who was best known for his portrayal of the gay stickup man Omar Little in the television series “The Wire.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: ‘Vladimir,’ a Debut That Celebrates Transgression — Up to a Point
description: In Julia May Jonas’s first novel, a married literature professor becomes obsessed with a younger experimental writer.
content: VLADIMIRBy Julia May Jonas239 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Swine Bomb’ Hits Bay Area, Tusks Flailing
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 2, 2022.
content: “I guess there are a lot of people who think, ‘That guy is a psychopath, he likes killing pigs.’ I don’t enjoy killing them. But they are terrible animals.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Mercy Street,’ by Jennifer Haigh: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Mercy Street,” by Jennifer Haigh
content: It’s hard to know, ever, where a story begins. We touch down in a world fully inhabited by others, a drama already in progress. By the time we make our entrance—incontinent and screaming, like dirty bombs detonating—the climax is a distant memory. Our arrival is not the beginning; it is a consequence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Thousands Mourn N.Y.P.D. Officer Whose Dreams Ended With Fatal Shooting
description: Wilbert Mora, one of two officers killed after responding to a 911 call in Harlem last month, was remembered at his funeral for his warmth and compassion.
content: A boy born in the Dominican Republic knew after he arrived in New York City, just 7 years old, that he wanted to be a police officer. And over the 20 years that followed, the boy grew tall and broad and earned his badge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Trial Guide: The U.S.S. Cole Bombing Case at Guantánamo Bay
description: What to know about the death-penalty prosecution of a Saudi prisoner accused of plotting the attack on a Navy destroyer off Yemen in 2000 that killed 17 sailors.
content: Saudi national Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri is accused of organizing the Qaeda bombing of the U.S. Navy destroyer Cole on Oct. 12, 2000. Two men sailed a bomb-laden skiff alongside the Cole during a routine refueling stop in the port of Aden, Yemen, then blew themselves up. Seventeen American sailors died, and dozens more were wounded. Mr. Nashiri is also accused of a role in the 2002 bombing of the Limburg, a French-flagged, Malaysian-chartered tanker that was carrying Iranian crude oil. A Bulgarian crew member was killed in that attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Dolly Parton, Eminem and A Tribe Called Quest Are Rock Hall Nominees
description: This year’s slate of 17 acts eligible for induction span rap, country, folk, pop and more.
content: Dolly Parton, Eminem, A Tribe Called Quest and Beck are among the first-time nominees on the ballot for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame this year, the organization behind the museum and annual ceremony announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Conservative Leader Is Ousted
description: The deposal of the Conservative leader Erin O’Toole could provide a political lift for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, buffeted by pandemic exhaustion.
content: MONTREAL — Erin O’Toole, the leader of Canada’s opposition Conservative Party, was ousted in a vote against his leadership on Wednesday, providing a political lift to the minority government of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, buffeted by pandemic fatigue and divided opinion over his stewardship of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Dana Rubinstein
title: Why These Women Are Determined to Clear Cuomo’s Name
description: Five months after Andrew Cuomo’s resignation, a small army of ardent loyalists is donating money and swarming social media to support the former governor.
content: Shelly Moore has never met Andrew M. Cuomo. She’s never lived in New York. Before the pandemic, she hadn’t even heard of him. “God’s honest truth,” she said, when reached by telephone last week in Jonesboro, Ga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Republicans Weigh How Forcefully to Fight a Black Female Court Nominee
description: Despite differences in ideology, Republicans recognize that an aggressive challenge comes with political peril.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s pledge to name a Black woman to fill a coming Supreme Court vacancy has thrust Republicans into a tricky political calculation, forcing them to confront how aggressive to be in opposing the nominee and how to do so without appearing to be racist and sexist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: How to Fix Child Care Before the Next Pandemic Wave
description: January was awful for parents and caregivers. We can do better.
content: In January, parents of kids under 5 told me they were in a state of despair and semi-panic; emotionally, they were at the lowest I’d heard them since the pandemic’s beginning in March 2020. The wait for vaccine approval for under-5s (which may be over soon) was a part of that. But another part of their upset was the fact that the expensive child care they were paying for was often unreliable: Children’s day care classes were routinely getting shut down because of too many coronavirus cases or because kids were getting sent home for quarantines of 10 days or longer based on exposure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Omicron’s Death Toll
description: Compared to other wealthy countries, the virus in the U.S. is killing people at much higher rates.
content: In the initial stages of the Omicron surge, American health officials looked at how other countries were withstanding the worst effects of the new variant and were reassured. But as the Omicron wave begins to subside, we’re getting a fuller picture of how the U.S. fared during the latest surge — and the data is sobering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Annotated by the Author: ‘Mycowood Violins: A Different Kind of Time Machine’
description: Natalia Araña, a winner of our 2021 STEM Writing Contest, tells us how she made an essay about violins relevant to readers’ lives.
content: In our annual STEM Writing Contest, we invite students to choose an issue or question in science, technology, engineering, math or health, and then write an engaging 500-word explanation of it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Black Cake,’ by Charmaine Wilkerson: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Black Cake,” by Charmaine Wilkerson
content: He should have known it would come to this. He should have known the day that hak gwai wife of his ran away from home. Should have known the day he saw his daughter swimming in the bay as a storm bore down on her. Should have known when his parents dragged him to this island and changed their names. He stood at the water’s edge, now, watching the waves crash white against the rocks, waiting for his daughter’s body to wash ashore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: When is the opening ceremony?
description: The Winter Games kick off Friday night at Beijing’s National Stadium.
content: The 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing begin this week with the opening ceremony on Friday, the official start of the Games. (Competition, it should be noted, will already be underway by then, in curling, women’s ice hockey and freestyle skiing; the Games — Winter or Summer — don’t easily fit in 17 days anymore.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: Can ‘Body Neutrality’ Change the Way You Work Out?
description: The key to staying active long term may be to care less about how you look and more about how you feel.
content: When I had a baby last summer — my first, a healthy boy — I knew that my body would be in rough shape afterward. Or, as my mother put it when I gingerly tried on a new pair of sweatpants one week post-birth: “Nothing is going to look good for a while. Try not to worry about it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meredith Mendelsohn
title: New Life for the Wyeth Legacy Five Miles Out to Sea
description: Colby College has acquired two islands off Maine that inspired the first family of American art, and will show newly discovered works that Andrew Wyeth drew in secret.
content: Nestled in the Atlantic Ocean, five miles off the coast of the picturesque town of Port Clyde, Maine, lie two rugged islands with stories to tell. Allen and Benner, as they are called, have witnessed a string of inhabitants over the centuries, from the Abenaki people and English colonists to homesteading lobstermen. And then came Betsy and Andrew Wyeth — mid-coast Maine locals and the most high-profile members of what many consider the first family of American art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Wembi and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: At Least 60 Dead in Attack on Camp for Displaced People in Congo
description: The attack, which was carried out with guns and machetes, was among the worst recorded in eastern Congo, a lush region where dozens of militant groups have wreaked havoc for years.
content: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — The families had fled their homes and farms to escape attacks by marauding militants, taking refuge in a makeshift camp for displaced people in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: What America Would Look Like in 2025 Under Trump
description: It’s not too soon to start worrying about the Republican agenda.
content: What will happen if the political tables are turned and the Republican Party wins the White House in 2024 and the House and Senate along the way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Guess Who Wants Your Money
description: Trump had his hand out 266 times in January.
content: Welcome to February! Any notable January accomplishments to report, people? Well, I received 266 email messages from Donald Trump, asking for money. Gotta be a lifetime achievement award in there somewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The federal trial of three former officers in the killing of George Floyd is postponed after one tests positive.
description: The court did not say which of the three defendants was infected with the coronavirus. The judge paused the proceedings at least until Monday.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — The federal trial of three former Minneapolis police officers charged with violating George Floyd’s civil rights was postponed on Wednesday after one of the former officers tested positive for the coronavirus, court officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Pfizer Asks F.D.A. to Clear 2 Vaccine Doses for Young Children as a Start
description: The Food and Drug Administration asked to review Pfizer’s data on two doses now, while the company continues to assess whether three doses would be more effective.
content: WASHINGTON — Pfizer and its partner, BioNTech, asked the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday to authorize two doses of their coronavirus vaccine for children younger than 5 while the companies continue to research whether three doses would be more effective for the age group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Vindman, Key Figure in Trump Impeachment, Alleges Retaliation in Lawsuit
description: The former Army colonel, who worked on the National Security Council, said in a lawsuit that Donald Trump Jr. and others carried out a campaign of intimidation against him.
content: Alexander Vindman, the Army colonel who was a chief witness in President Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment trial, filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against Mr. Trump’s son, Donald Trump Jr.; Rudolph W. Giuliani; and two other top Trump White House aides, accusing them of running a coordinated intimidation and retaliation campaign to stop him from testifying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Makiko Inoue
title: Shintaro Ishihara, Outspoken Nationalist Governor of Tokyo, Dies at 89
description: An author as well as a politician, he was known for feuding with China over disputed islands and calling for Japan to assert itself against the United States.
content: Shintaro Ishihara, a Japanese author turned firebrand nationalist politician who served as the governor of Tokyo and famously stoked diplomatic tensions with China over disputed islands, died on Tuesday in Tokyo. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: In ‘Prayer for the French Republic,’ Echoes of the Past
description: Joshua Harmon’s ambitious new play toggles between a contemporary Jewish family facing growing antisemitism and their relatives during World War II.
content: The well of naïve young Americans being schooled in life, love, politics and croissants by effortlessly worldly French people is in no danger of running dry. The latest addition to this cohort is 20-year-old Molly, a New Yorker who has just met her distant cousins in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: A Venice Biennale Informed by the Pandemic Will Spotlight Women
description: For the 59th edition of the longest-running survey of contemporary art, Cecilia Alemani selected mostly female artists, many of color, from around the world.
content: In the two years that the New York-based curator Cecilia Alemani had to organize the 59th edition of the Venice Biennale — during which the pandemic forced a one-year delay and 400 studio visits had to happen on Zoom — the world changed around her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Conditions at a General Motors Plant in Mexico Spur a Labor Challenge
description: Mexican salaries are low, partly because of unions that collude with employers. Workers at a G.M. factory are challenging that system, testing the labor reforms in the reworked North American trade deal.
content: SILAO, Mexico — When he got a job with General Motors in Mexico, Guillermo Ramírez thought it was his ticket out of poverty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The U.S. selects Elana Meyers Taylor as a flag bearer and then has to replace her.
description: Brittany Bowe, a three-time Olympic speedskater, was selected to step in for Meyers Taylor, who was selected by her teammates but tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: The United States picked two flag bearers for the opening ceremony on Friday, and then immediately replaced one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mooj Zadie, Rachelle Bonja, Austin Mitchell, Marc Georges, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Dan Powell
title: The Trump Plan to Seize Voting Machines
description: The Times has unearthed Donald Trump’s most brazen attempt yet to overturn the 2020 election.
content: Since the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, reporters and the specially appointed House Jan. 6 committee have been trying to achieve a clearer picture of the steps that President Donald J. Trump and his allies took to try to keep him in power and overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Clad in a Kimono, a Painter of Warriors Returns to Downtown New York
description: Chaz Guest, a favorite of Oprah, the Obamas and Angelina Jolie, has a gallery show featuring the actor Michael K. Williams, who modeled just before he died.
content: The figurative painter Chaz Guest has fans in high places. Collectors of his work include the Obamas — who displayed his portrait of Thurgood Marshall, the first Black Supreme Court justice, in the White House — and Oprah Winfrey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alastair Macaulay
title: Birju Maharaj, Virtuoso of Classical Indian Dance, Dies at 83
description: Mr. Maharaj choreographed for Bollywood, but was chiefly known for carrying the torch of Kathak, one of India’s major dance traditions.
content: Birju Maharaj, who was revered in India as an exponent of one of its most ancient and established classical dance forms, and who choreographed steps for Bollywood hits and Indian movie classics by directors like Satyajit Ray, died on Jan. 16 in New Delhi. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Pam & Tommy’: A Story of Sex, Crimes and Videotape
description: A new Hulu series starring Lily James and Sebastian Stan is a picaresque romp through the history of the stolen sex tape that changed pop culture.
content: Back when 1995 was young, Pamela Anderson and her new husband, Tommy Lee, the drummer for the flashy metal combo Mötley Crüe, were on top of the world. She was starring in the TV hit “Baywatch,” and while his band was past its 1980s prime, he could still live la vida rocka in their Malibu mansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Inside Beijing’s Olympic Bubble: Robots, Swabs and a Big Gamble
description: There are multiple tests and guards and anxious Olympians as China stages the Games under a “zero Covid” bet. Our correspondent’s journey into the walled-off maze.
content: BEIJING — The strategy is audacious and stifling, and that is very much the point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: ‘An Environmentalist With a Gun’: Inside Steven Rinella’s Hunting Empire
description: With “MeatEater” on Netflix and a growing roster of podcasts, he is teaching a new kind of hunter about how killing animals can be part of loving nature.
content: There’s an episode of ‘‘MeatEater,’’ the hunting reality show on Netflix, in which the New York Mets first baseman Pete Alonso shoots a mule deer. After he watches it stumble, then fall dead on the ground — this is in the San Juan Mountains of Southern Colorado — he puts his head in his hand. “I think my grandpa is really proud,” he says, his voice shaky with adrenaline and emotion; his grandfather, who died a few years earlier, took him hunting and fishing as a boy. Then he turns to Steven Rinella, the lanky 47-year-old star of the show. “Thank you, Steve,” he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Sara Ramirez Is Not Che Diaz
description: Ramirez doesn’t really relate to Che, the most polarizing character in “And Just Like That.” But the actor is “really proud of the representation that we’ve created.”
content: During a much-discussed “comedy concert” in “And Just Like That …,” HBO’s “Sex and the City” sequel series, the much-discussed character Che Diaz recounts the story of coming out to family members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Lessons of Brooklyn Tech
description: The principle of equality should strengthen the ideal of merit, not obstruct it.
content: For many years I lived across the street from Stuyvesant High School, Manhattan’s elite public school, and I would sometimes get a ride from a father of one of the students. He was a cabdriver from Pakistan, a man who liked to strike up conversations with his passengers. Usually we talked about two things: his pride in his academically gifted kids (another child was already at Cornell) and his dismay at the state of affairs in Pakistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Should Spotify Do About Joe Rogan?
description: The streaming service argues it isn’t responsible for moderating Covid-19 misinformation spread by its star podcaster. What do you think?
content: Please note: Our Student Opinion questions specifically invite the voices of young people. We ask that adults respect the intent of this forum and refrain from posting here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Display a Little Spirit
description: Meredith Colton Hazy makes her New York Times debut.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Meredith Colton Hazy on her New York Times Crossword debut! Ms. Hazy is the eighth debut constructor of 2022. Her puzzle today brings us a new twist on a classic theme type, along with some stellar wordplay clues and, with the exception of one tricky cross, a boatload of clean fill. What more could you ask of a Wednesday debut?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Talks Tom Brady’s Retirement
description: “You know you’ve been around a long time when you debuted the same year as ‘The Thong Song,’” Jimmy Fallon joked on Tuesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Wealth Inequality Is the Highest Since World War II
description: During the pandemic, the rich got a lot richer.
content: Gross domestic product is a useful metric of a nation’s economic success, but what you’d also like to know is who reaps the benefit when it grows — the rich, the poor, the middle class or everyone. During the pandemic, for example, we know that government benefits helped the poor, while stimulative monetary policy pushed up stock prices and benefited the rich in particular. What was the net result?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Yale to Evaluate Policies on Donor Gifts and Influence
description: Plans for a new faculty committee to protect academic freedom came after the head of a prestigious program resigned, citing donor interference.
content: Four months after reports that the head of one its most prestigious programs had abruptly resigned, Yale University is forming a committee to review its gift policies to ensure that academic freedom would be safeguarded from undue donor influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Where a Thousand Digital Eyes Keep Watch Over the Elderly
description: As Japan rapidly ages, it is envisioning fundamental changes, even in infrastructure. Is electronic surveillance an answer to its epidemic of dementia?
content: ITAMI, Japan — In his early 70s, Koji Uchida began to vanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: What the ‘Active Grandparent Hypothesis’ Can Tell Us About Aging Well
description: The need for healthy, active grandparents who can help with child-rearing may be encoded in our genes.
content: Why is physical activity so good for us as we age? According to a novel new theory about exercise, evolution and aging, the answer lies, in part, in our ancestral need for grandparents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Football Vocabulary, Cold-Water Plunges, Comics Reporting
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn how to illustrate their feelings, reflect on their experiences with cold water, meet a Times comics reporter, listen to the pronunciation of a new word and use football vocabulary in context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democrats Break With Leaders Over Congressional Stock Trading
description: With top House Democrats skeptical of barring lawmakers from owning individual stocks, a simmering issue has exploded, especially among members facing difficult re-election races.
content: WASHINGTON — Facing stiff political headwinds and a flagging election-year agenda, the most vulnerable Democrats in Congress have found a way to distance themselves from their leaders: demanding an end to stock trading for all members of Congress, including senior lawmakers who are clearly leery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Emily Cochrane
title: Senator Ben Ray Luján Recovering After Suffering Stroke
description: Any prolonged absence by the New Mexico Democrat threatens to impede the agenda of his party, which controls the Senate by the slimmest of margins.
content: Senator Ben Ray Luján, Democrat of New Mexico, suffered a stroke last week and is expected to make a full recovery, his chief of staff said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The U.S. Army will begin dismissing vaccine holdouts.
description: Other branches of the military, including the Air Force, have already begun discharging members who refused to comply with the mandate.
content: American soldiers who have yet to be vaccinated against the coronavirus will be immediately discharged, the Army said on Wednesday, joining other branches of the military, including the Navy and Air Force, that have already begun dismissing vaccine holdouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Edward Wong
title: In Clash With U.S. Over Ukraine, Putin Has a Lifeline From China
description: President Biden could find his plans to punish Russia undermined by Xi Jinping, a longtime ally of Mr. Putin. But China moves cautiously during crises.
content: BEIJING — As the United States moves to exert maximal pressure on Russia over fears of a Ukraine invasion, the Russian leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has found relief from his most powerful partner on the global stage, China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Katie Benner and Giulia Heyward
title: Six Juveniles Are Persons of Interest in Threats to Historically Black Colleges
description: The F.B.I. said it was investigating the bomb threats, which disrupted life on more than a dozen campuses, as racially or ethnically motivated violent extremism and hate crimes.
content: The F.B.I. has identified six juveniles as persons of interest in a series of bomb threats that targeted historically Black colleges and universities, a law enforcement official said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: broach
description: This word has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word broach has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 6 in “Told to ‘Find Arthur,’ I Stumbled Upon My Future at the U.S. Open” by Kurt Streeter:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Wordle
description: Do you play? What do you think about the fact that The Times has purchased the game?
content: Wordle is a game in which once a day players get six chances to guess a five-letter word. It has had a meteoric rise: It first appeared in October; had 90 users on Nov. 1; and now millions play the game daily. Have you ever played? If not, try it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: This District Attorney Is Fighting Crime — and Angering the Police
description: Studies show public safety improves when prosecutors turn to alternatives to jailing some offenders.
content: After he was sworn into office last month, the new district attorney for Manhattan, Alvin Bragg, issued a memo that caused widespread confusion and great consternation among police unions, the city’s new police commissioner and conservative politicians. The widow of one of two police officers killed in January called him out in her eulogy last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Shashank Bengali
title: Five Takeaways on Ukraine Crisis, After Putin Breaks Silence
description: The threat of conflict may not have passed, despite a flurry of diplomacy in Moscow and Kyiv.
content: When he spoke about Ukraine on Tuesday for the first time in over a month, President Vladimir V. Putin’s signal that Russia was open to a diplomatic resolution to the crisis seemed to cool temperatures — at least for the moment. But it also illustrated the vast gulf between Moscow’s demands and what Western nations are even willing to discuss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: House Hunting in Aruba: Three Bedrooms and a Pool for $1.1 Million
description: Sitting just outside the Caribbean hurricane belt, the Dutch island of Aruba has seen its home market bounce back with pandemic buyers.
content: This contemporary-style villa overlooks an 18-hole golf course in the gated Tierra del Sol community, on the northwest coast of Aruba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘2022 Beijing Winter Olympics: Answers to Some Big Questions’
description: In this lesson, students will learn more about the upcoming Winter Olympics and consider how participating nations should address human rights abuses by China.
content: Featured Article: “2022 Beijing Winter Olympics: Answers to Some Big Questions”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Goodridge
title: 6 Days, 8 Dives and Breathtaking Beauty Off the Coast of Honduras
description: The waters encircling the island of Roatán offer some of the most accessible reef diving anywhere. As travel picks up, the focus is on balancing the return of tourism (and divers) with the fragility of the marine environment.
content: Scuba divers are much like children, I imagine, to dive-resort owners: They are almost always wonderful to have, but at night, it’s best if they are safely in their beds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Shulevitz
title: Savior? Monster? A Messianic Leader Rallies His Followers.
description: The Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk‘s novel “The Books of Jacob” is based on the life of the self-proclaimed messiah Jacob Frank.
content: THE BOOKS OF JACOBBy Olga TokarczukTranslated by Jennifer Croft
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Valentine’s Trees? Sure, Why Not.
description: Retailers, keen to cash in on a Hallmark holiday, have been selling pink plastic trees and oversized conversation hearts to adorn them. Now they’re popping up on crafty corners of the internet.
content: Sandra Di Carlo Valdez looked at her Christmas tree in January and felt a wave of sadness. One week into 2022 and nearly two years into a pandemic, the tree was a source of joy; she wasn’t ready to take it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich and Sam Youkilis
title: It’s Gold, Baby. But Niclas Castello’s Cube Is Nothing New in Art.
description: The artist’s solid gold cube, which appeared for one day in Central Park, was Instagram bait, an NFT promotion and even kind of pretty.
content: The fun thing about conceptual art is that it’s totally easy to create. You can say something about the increasingly virtual way many of us experience the world, and the explosive popularity of NFTs (nonfungible tokens) — or seem to say something profound, anyway — just by staging a Central Park happening around a knee-high cube of 24-karat gold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Sends Top Security Official to Help NATO Brace for Russian Cyberattacks
description: Intelligence assessments suggest that a Russian invasion of Ukraine would most likely be preceded by cyberattacks on Ukraine’s electric grid, its communications systems and its government.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House dispatched its top cybersecurity official to NATO on Tuesday in what it described as a mission to prepare allies to deter, and perhaps disrupt, Russian cyberattacks on Ukraine, and to brace for the possibility that sanctions on Moscow could lead to a wave of retaliatory cyberattacks on Europe and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Gina Kolata
title: Biden Presents Ambitious Plan to Cut Cancer Death Rate in Half
description: The president aims to revive the cancer “moonshot” program, but experts expressed doubt that it would be possible to reduce the death rate so profoundly.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden unveiled a plan on Wednesday to reduce the death rate from cancer by at least 50 percent over the next 25 years — an ambitious new goal, he said, to “supercharge” the cancer “moonshot” program he initiated and presided over five years ago as vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Biden Administration Rejects Use of Testimony Obtained From Torture in Guantánamo Trial
description: The Justice Department rejected an interpretation by the retired chief prosecutor that lawyers could sometimes use statements obtained during C.I.A. interrogations.
content: The Biden administration has pledged to no longer invoke statements made by a prisoner during his years in C.I.A. custody in his death-penalty proceedings, repudiating an earlier effort to use evidence obtained from torture in a case at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Bright
title: The Clues to the Next Variant Surge Are All Around Us
description: Wastewater monitoring and air sampling hold promise for finding viruses and variants faster.
content: When scientists in South Africa noticed an uptick in Covid-19 cases in the Gauteng Province last November, they began investigating the source. These researchers and others in Botswana quickly discovered the Omicron variant and heroically shared their discovery with the rest of the world. And yet it was still too late — Omicron was already rapidly infecting people across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Mel Mermelstein, Holocaust Survivor Who Sued Deniers, Dies at 95
description: He accused a revisionist history group of reneging on its promise to give a reward to anyone who could prove that the Nazis gassed Jews. He won his case.
content: Mel Mermelstein, an Auschwitz survivor who, by calling the bluff of self-proclaimed World War II historical revisionists, won a formal apology, $90,000 and a judge’s affirmation that the Holocaust indisputably happened, died on Friday at his home in Long Beach, Calif. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A Cancer Treatment Makes Leukemia Vanish, but Creates More Mysteries
description: Two early recipients of CAR T immunotherapy were free of a blood cancer nearly a decade after receiving the therapy.
content: Doug Olson was feeling kind of tired in 1996. When a doctor examined him she frowned. “I don’t like the feel of those lymph nodes,” she said, poking his neck. She ordered a biopsy. The result was terrifying. He had chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a blood cancer that mostly strikes older people and accounts for about a quarter of new cases of leukemia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Panel Says Some Havana Syndrome Cases May Stem From Radio Energy
description: A group of experts found that not all injuries to diplomats and C.I.A. officers could be explained by stress or psychosomatic reactions.
content: WASHINGTON — A panel of experts assembled by the Biden administration concluded on Wednesday that stress or psychosomatic reactions could not explain some of the incidents of Havana syndrome they had reviewed, and said that radio waves could have caused some of the injuries among C.I.A. officers and diplomats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Neil Young and Liz Cheney, Thanks for Sticking Your Necks Out
description: We need truth and trust for our democracy, our health and our planet.
content: In an era when so many leaders in American public life are behaving badly, I never want to miss a chance to give a shout-out to those daring to stick out their necks on principle. So, Representative Liz Cheney and singer-songwriter Neil Young — this Bud’s for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Oakland District Weighs Closing Schools Amid Budget Shortage
description: More than a dozen schools could be either shuttered or merged before the fall.
content: What is typically a dull affair, a weeknight meeting of a school board, was anything but on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Why Are Oil Prices So High and Will They Stay That Way?
description: Geopolitical tensions and a growing disparity between supply and demand have driven up prices. Here is what that means and what could happen next.
content: HOUSTON — Oil prices are increasing, again, casting a shadow over the economy, driving up inflation and eroding consumer confidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Who Will Be Nominated for the Oscars? Here Are Our Projections.
description: The list will be unveiled Feb. 8. Our expert’s predictions are based on precursor awards and industry scuttlebutt. But in an unusually open year, he’d love to be wrong.
content: This year’s Oscar nominations, set to be announced on Feb. 8, feel unusually up for grabs: With the diminished Golden Globes off the air and the Critics Choice Awards pushed back to March because of the Omicron variant, no televised awards show has had the chance to dominate the run-up to these selections, and Oscar voters may gravitate toward some surprising picks as a result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Abelson
title: The Name of This Interviewee Is David Byrne
description: In advance of a show of his drawings at New York’s Pace Gallery, the polymathic performer answered T’s Artist’s Questionnaire.
content: The January afternoon I met David Byrne in his office in a SoHo loft was otherwise bleak and cold. Upstairs, in a dark turtleneck sweater and dark mask, and with a white shock of hair, the musician, drawer, performer, filmmaker, diarist, photographer, bicycle rider and Talking Heads co-founder was laughing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Putin blames the U.S. for the standoff over Ukraine.
content: Speaking at a news conference in Moscow yesterday, Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, said that the U.S. was trying to pull Russia into an armed conflict over Ukraine that Russia did not want. He signaled he was prepared to engage in more diplomacy, even as he insisted that NATO’s presence in Eastern Europe threatened world peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: With oil markets tightening, OPEC and its allies agree to a small increase in output.
description: High prices and strong demand would suggest it was time for a major increase, but uncertainty around Ukraine leaves the oil producers in an awkward spot.
content: Officials from OPEC countries and their allies agreed on Wednesday to continue feeding a modest amount of additional oil into an increasingly tight market, a move that may add new uncertainty to energy markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Is There Medical Neglect in New York City Jails?
description: A court filing says missed appointments lead to serious health consequences.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at medical care in New York City jails, which lawyers for incarcerated people say is inadequate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland, Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Biden Promised 500 Million Free Covid Tests. Then He Had to Find Them.
description: Millions of Americans are now receiving tests through the new mail program, which health experts said came too late to meet demand during the brunt of Omicron wave.
content: WASHINGTON — As the United States saw a nearly vertical increase in coronavirus cases in late December and a growing backlash over a shortage of rapid tests, President Biden promised that his administration would mail 500 million of them to Americans, free of charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump’s Words, and Deeds, Reveal Depths of His Drive to Retain Power
description: Donald Trump said he wanted Mike Pence to overturn the election, dangled pardons for Jan. 6 rioters and called for protests against prosecutors. Now, it turns out, he had discussed having national security agencies seize voting machines.
content: A series of new remarks by Donald J. Trump about the aftermath of the 2020 election and new disclosures about his actions in trying to forestall its result — including discussing the use of the national security apparatus to seize voting machines — have stripped away any pretense that the events of Jan. 6, 2021, were anything but the culmination of the former president’s single-minded pursuit of retaining power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Investors See Hope in Big Corporate Profits
description: Alphabet, Exxon Mobil, UPS and others gave shareholders reasons to stay optimistic.
content: We are almost at the halfway point for earnings season, and jittery investors are looking to corporate financial reports for direction after inflation, geopolitics and other worries dragged down markets last month. It’s been a different story in the past few days, though, as robust earnings reports steadied nerves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Winter Storm Tears Across Three U.S. Time Zones
description: Forecasters warned of dangerous icing in the Mid-Atlantic and South as the Midwest dug out from a blast of snow.
content: CHICAGO — A sprawling storm blocked highways, closed schools and canceled flights across much of the central United States on Wednesday, with nearly a foot of snow piling up in parts of the Midwest while areas to the south braced for potentially dangerous accumulations of ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Safak Timur
title: 12 Migrants Freeze to Death, Stripped by Greek Guards, Turkey Says
description: A Turkish minister accused Greek border guards of taking the group’s clothes and shoes and then forcing them back across the border, a claim that Greece denied.
content: ISTANBUL — Twelve migrants died on Wednesday in Turkey, most of them found with little clothing in a freezing field near the border with Greece, according to several Turkish officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Do Democrats Win When They Talk About Race?
description: The party in power’s internal debate ahead of the midterms: appeal to moderate swing voters or unite the base against racism?
content: With the midterm elections just nine months away, the Democrats face some hefty existential questions that need answers: Who are they in this post- and possibly pre-Trump era of American politics? Are they simply the anti-Trump party? Or are they the party of progress? Who are the voters they need to turn out in November? Should they excite the base by building a coalition united against white supremacy, or should they moderate their message to win over Republican-defectors?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Who Are the Key Figures of Interest in the Jan. 6 Inquiry?
description: The list of names being scrutinized by the House committee for their role in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol keeps growing.
content: A House select committee has been formed to scrutinize the causes of the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol. The riot occurred as Congress met to formalize Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s election victory amid efforts by President Donald J. Trump and his allies to overturn the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Carp
title: The Man Who Fought Homelessness and Won (Sort Of)
description: Steven Banks was the most effective social-services director in New York City history — and when he left office, there were still 45,000 people sleeping in shelters. Is that a success?
content: A little past midnight one June evening two years ago, Steven Banks, then the commissioner of New York City’s Department of Social Services, arrived at the Coney Island-Stillwell Avenue subway station, in South Brooklyn, to help see passengers off the trains. For the past seven weeks, the subway system had been closing for four hours each night — the first planned overnight shutdown in more than a century. Transit officials had explained the shutdown as a chance for a “deep cleaning” in the face of the pandemic, but at a news conference, Gov. Andrew Cuomo admitted that the decision would deny homeless New Yorkers a place to sleep. Banks’s department had received four days’ notice, and it was all hands on deck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody Rosen
title: Why Is Matt Damon Shilling for Crypto?
description: Just buy it, he seems to suggest; what are you, a wimp?
content: “History,” Matt Damon says, “is filled with almosts.” He’s got a point. He is in a cavernous gallery space, delivering lines that almost make sense, with an affect that almost seems human. On the one hand, he tells us, the annals are haunted by “those who almost adventured, who almost achieved, but ultimately, for them, it proved to be too much.” Yet there are others: “the ones who embrace the moment and commit.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: How One Ski Town Rallied in a Warming World
description: A community in Vermont took charge after the local hill closed.
content: When the Mount Ascutney ski resort closed in 2010 because of scant snow and mismanagement, it threatened to take with it the nearby community of West Windsor, Vt., population 1,099.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why Gardeners Should Stop Using Peat, and What to Use Instead
description: Finding a substitute for peat is a little like making your first cake without gluten. Here’s what the experts advise.
content: Environmental leaders and other high-profile voices like Monty Don, the British horticulturist, author and broadcaster, have been sounding the cry: Gardeners should stop using peat, because the consequences of its continued harvest on diverse peatland habitats, and the native plants and animals that inhabit them, are too high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Confusion, frustration and tears: a Belgian Olympian’s day in isolation.
description: Kim Meylemans’s case underscored the concerns many visitors had expressed before the Games in China, which is enforcing a so-called zero-Covid strategy.
content: Through tears, Kim Meylemans explained how she had thought her nightmare was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. to Send Troops to Eastern Europe
description: The move may reassure NATO allies anxious over tensions surrounding Ukraine.
content: President Biden has approved the deployment of about 3,000 additional U.S. troops to Eastern Europe to reassure NATO allies anxious over tensions surrounding Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: One Day in the ‘Parallel Universe’ of a London I.C.U.
description: Britain’s government may have lifted coronavirus restrictions, but hospital workers say the return to a normal rhythm of work is still a long way off.
content: LONDON — A gaggle of masked nurses and doctors in blue paper gowns shuffled from one coronavirus patient to the next offering lifesaving care. Some patients had lingered for days or weeks. Others counted their stays in months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karin Lipson
title: Boerum Hill, Brooklyn: A ‘Village in the City’
description: With its desirable 19th-century rowhouses and convenient subway access, the neighborhood is both homey and worldly.
content: Katie McShane and her husband, James O’Reilly, were apartment-hunting in Brooklyn in 2017 when they noticed a “for sale” sign in front of a brick townhouse in Boerum Hill. Ms. McShane, now 36, was intrigued. Mr. O’Reilly, 38, recalls thinking, “There’s no way we could afford a townhouse.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: I Swapped My Reading Glasses for Magical Eyedrops
description: Vuity, taken daily, promises clear vision for up to 10 hours. But does it work?
content: I never set out to become a middle-aged woman known for jazzy eyewear but that’s exactly who I am.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: John C. Koss, Stereo Headphone Innovator, Is Dead at 91
description: The sound “was just bouncing in my ears,” he said of his first experience with the earliest version of the headphones he helped invent in 1958.
content: John C. Koss, a trumpet player and onetime teenage bandleader who with a friend invented stereo headphones and provided people with a new high-quality — and personal — way to listen to music, died on Dec. 21 in Milwaukee. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Tonga, struck by twin disasters, goes into lockdown over five virus cases.
description: Among the infected are two workers who were helping to distribute aid shipments at the Tongan wharf after a volcanic eruption and tsunami tested positive.
content: Tonga went into lockdown on Wednesday evening after recording its first community transmission of the coronavirus, weeks after being battered by a powerful volcanic eruption and subsequent tsunami. The eruption shrouded buildings in ash, swamped the island with water, cut off digital communication and prompted an international humanitarian aid effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: OMG, You’ll Never Believe What the Laser Vacuum Revealed
description: High-tech vacuums and robotic mops are having their moment in a pandemic that has contributed to never-ending messes at home.
content: On a recent Friday night, I unpacked the newest Dyson vacuum to try it out (as people do with their free time in a pandemic). As someone who tests lots of cutting-edge gizmos, I wasn’t expecting to be blown away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How Hugh Jackman, Sutton Foster and ‘The Music Man’ Withstood Covid
description: Nearly 60 cast and crew members have tested positive since rehearsals began. Now, following a 10-day shutdown during previews, opening night is near.
content: As soon as Hugh Jackman learned that the leading lady of “The Music Man,” Sutton Foster — whom he spent a substantial portion of every night breathing on, sweating on and locking lips with onstage — had tested positive for the coronavirus, he knew it was just a matter of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Westover
title: I Am Not Proof of the American Dream
description: For poor kids today, the path I took through education no longer exists.
content: When I think of my first semester of college, the memory comes to me as a physical sensation. I feel tired. There is the siren-screech of an alarm sounding at 3:40 in the morning. I feel it in my teeth. Then images: the orange glow of the jumbo numbers in pitch black, the instinctual, semiconscious tapping of the button, the gradual shrinking of my bed as I climb out of it and move toward the door. I do not change my clothes. It was my habit to dress for the day the night before, because an alarm blaring at 3:40 really does sound much better than an alarm blaring at 3:30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Europe labels nuclear and natural gas as sustainable investments.
description: The effort to steer public and private money toward nuclear power stations and gas-fired generators in the European Union was criticized as greenwashing.
content: The European Union said on Wednesday that it would label some nuclear power and natural gas plants, under certain conditions, as “transitional” green investments in order to drastically cut the continent’s greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Music for Dance
description: Reggae, house, step, ballet, tap, jazz: Listen to the sounds that have inspired great choreographers.
content: In the past we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion, symphonies, Stravinsky, trumpet, Maria Callas, Bach, the organ and mezzo-sopranos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: A ‘Master Class’ in Gerrymandering, This Time Led by N.Y. Democrats
description: The maps approved by Democrats in the New York State Legislature could lead their party to seize as many as three House seats from Republicans.
content: Democrats across the nation have spent years railing against partisan gerrymandering, particularly in Republican states — most recently trying to pass federal voting rights legislation in Washington to all but outlaw the practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Covid Vaccine We Need Now May Not Be a Shot
description: Nasal vaccines under development around the world may make better boosters by stopping the coronavirus in the airways.
content: HYDERABAD, India — On the outskirts of this centuries-old Indian city, a world away from its congested roads and cacophony, the gleaming modern laboratories of Bharat Biotech are churning out a Covid vaccine that would be sprayed into the nose rather than injected into the blood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: So, You Think the Republican Party No Longer Represents the People
description: American liberalism needs to democratize itself, too.
content: “There is no sense in avoiding or diluting the magnitude of this turn in our story: One major political party no longer accepts democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta spent $10 billion on the metaverse in 2021, dragging down profit.
description: Quarterly profits decreased 8 percent, to $10.3 billion, from a year earlier. Shares of Meta’s stock plunged about 22 percent in after-hours trading.
content: Mark Zuckerberg said his company was going all in on the metaverse last year. On Wednesday, he showed the costs of making that transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google Vanquished a Rival in Prague. Payback Could Hurt.
description: A small search engine company in the Czech Republic helped inspire a law that is poised to put major limits on tech giants like Google.
content: As Google extended its dominance as a search engine over the past two decades, the Czech Republic stood out as a surprising holdout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Astronomers Find a New Asteroid Sharing Earth’s Orbit
description: The Trojan asteroid 2020 XL5, which follows the same path around the sun as our planet, was revealed only after a decade of searching.
content: Astronomers have discovered a captive asteroid shadowing Earth in its orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Republicans Who Voted to Impeach Trump Out-Raised Primary Rivals
description: Despite their pariah status in their party, House Republicans who broke with the former president have raised more than their G.O.P. foes.
content: WASHINGTON — All seven House Republicans who voted to impeach former President Donald J. Trump and are seeking re-election have out-raised their primary opponents, many of whom have received Mr. Trump’s backing, according to campaign disclosures filed with the Federal Election Commission this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Part-Time Work During a Labor Shortage
description: A tight job market is unlikely to reverse inequality.
content: Brenda Garcia, who works at a Chipotle in Queens, has a problem that may sound surprising in today’s tight labor market. She is a part-time employee who wants more work, but the restaurant keeps assigning her less than 20 hours a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: ‘The Lost City’ and a Richard Linklater Film Will Play SXSW
description: The film festival will return to primarily in-person screenings in Austin, Texas, with some online options.
content: Moon landings, multiverses and the movie-star musings of Nicolas Cage will all be a part of this year’s South by Southwest Film Festival lineup, organizers announced Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Americans Can’t Quit SMS
description: The world loves WhatsApp and other texting apps. Americans are chatting in their own bubble.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: Where Have All the Flowers Gone?
description: Supply chain challenges, labor shortages and poor growing conditions have led to a global shortage of fresh flowers, especially the kinds grown for events like weddings.
content: The photographs of trashed flowers still haunt florists. In 2020, when much of the world went into lockdown because of the pandemic, many flower farms’ crops were discarded. Since no one knew what was going to happen, new crops were not planted as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Lyman
title: Monica Vitti, ‘Queen of Italian Cinema,’ Dies at 90
description: Both sensual and cerebral, she made her mark on the international scene in the 1960s, when visionary directors like Michelangelo Antonioni were remaking the cinema landscape.
content: Monica Vitti, whose chilly sensuality and cerebral approach to her roles enlivened a groundbreaking series of 1960s film masterpieces directed by Michelangelo Antonioni, including the much-debated “L’Avventura,” died on Wednesday in Rome. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Andrew E. Kramer
title: In Responses to Russia, U.S. Stands Firm on Who Can Join NATO
description: Leaked replies to Moscow’s security demands reinforced the intractability of a crisis that threatens to lead to war.
content: BRUSSELS — The confrontation between Russia and the United States over Ukraine deepened on Wednesday, as leaked documents confirmed the U.S. and NATO rejection of key Russian security demands, while the Biden administration ordered 3,000 additional troops into Eastern Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Azeen Ghorayshi
title: N.C.A.A. to Review U.S.A. Swimming’s New Policy for Transgender Athletes
description: The new policy requires that transgender women show lowered testosterone levels for 36 months. It is not clear whether it will be used during the N.C.A.A. swimming championships in March.
content: The N.C.A.A. said Wednesday that it was uncertain whether a new U.S.A. Swimming policy for transgender athletes, which increases the burden of proof for transgender women to show that they do not have a competitive advantage against cisgender women, would be adopted ahead of next month’s N.C.A.A. swimming championships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Last Looks’ Review: A Hollywood Murder Mystery Full of Clichés
description: A former police officer is drawn back into duty in a case involving a drunken TV star, played by Mel Gibson, and the plot thickens.
content: Latter-day Hollywood murder mysteries, from “The Long Goodbye” to “The Dead Pool” to “Kiss Kiss Bang Bang,” provide filmmakers welcome outlets for both showbiz sensationalism and a little (at least) biting of the hand that feeds them. Oh, and sometimes cliché-mongering. “Last Looks,” directed by Tim Kirkby and based on a novel by Howard Michael Gould, opens with an ex-cop living in self-imposed ascetic exile, a circumstance that now feels as old as time, if not older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: The Power of Telling a Story Through Audio
description: Though narrated articles, The Times is connecting with its audience in a new — and personal — way.
content: First, Brian X. Chen, the lead consumer technology writer for The New York Times, tucked himself into a tiny corner of his basement, a spot where he usually keeps his luggage. Then, he propped up his dog’s bed on the wall behind him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: NATO, Winter Storm, Beijing Olympics: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Shaila Dewan
title: How a Plea Deal in the Arbery Hate Crime Case Unraveled
description: Prosecutors thought they had come up with an ironclad deal to put Ahmaud Arbery’s killers away. But for his family, it wasn’t enough.
content: ATLANTA — Tara M. Lyons stood in a courtroom in Brunswick, Ga., this week with a dilemma no prosecutor wants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: He Suffered Under Romania’s Dictatorship. Then He Was Forced to Spy for It.
description: Ruta Sepetys’s latest historical Y.A. novel, “I Must Betray You,” follows the life of a teenager who is blackmailed to become an informer for a repressive Communist regime.
content: Welcome to YA/NYT, a monthly column in which we recommend one new young adult book that you won’t want to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann, Natalie Proulx and C. Ross Flatt
title: Want to Write About Science? Former New York Times Journalists Give Advice.
description: In five short videos, Nicholas St. Fleur and Katherine J. Wu share tips to help students sharpen their informational writing skills.
content: Note: Our 2022 STEM Writing Contest is open from Feb. 2 to March 9.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: Grindr is pulled from Apple’s App Store in China.
description: The dating app removed itself from Apple’s platform in China because of concerns over data regulations.
content: Executives with Grindr, the world’s most popular gay dating app, have pulled it from Apple’s App Store in China over concerns about data regulations, the latest in a series of foreign departures from the Chinese market following new rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Tennessee State Senator Expelled From Office Over Conviction
description: State Senators voted 27 to 5 to remove Katrina Robinson from office over a wire fraud conviction. She has denied wrongdoing, and called the move “an attack on the Black vote.”
content: The Tennessee State Senate voted on Wednesday to remove a senator from office because of her conviction on federal wire fraud charges, the first time the chamber has removed a senator since at least the Civil War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: Jeff Zucker Resigns From CNN After Relationship With Top Executive
description: The relationship came up during the network’s investigation into the former anchor Chris Cuomo. “I was required to disclose it when it began but I didn’t,” Mr. Zucker wrote in a memo to colleagues.
content: Jeff Zucker resigned on Wednesday as the president of CNN, departing one of the most powerful positions in American media after acknowledging that he had failed to disclose a romantic relationship with another senior executive at the network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: As Boris Johnson Seeks a Reset, More Tory Lawmakers Defect
description: Britain’s prime minister tried to steer attention away from a damning report on Downing Street parties, but his support continued to erode.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson tried to change the subject on Wednesday, hoping to replace the public image of himself as a heedless partygoer with that of a confident global statesman and a farsighted nation builder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘MJ,’ No One’s Looking at the Man in the Mirror
description: A new jukebox musical tells the story of Michael Jackson. Except for the big story.
content: “There are a lot of strange stories making the rounds,” says a documentary filmmaker interviewing Michael Jackson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Watch These 11 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
description: February’s exodus includes two best picture winners and a lot more. Catch these while you can.
content: As awards season builds, this month’s departures from Netflix in the United States include two best picture winners, alongside a handful of comedies that did not tickle the Academy’s fancy. Also leaving Netflix this month: a propulsive crime thriller, a generous helping of science fiction and a delightfully decadent documentary. Check out these 11 titles while you can. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Heti
title: ‘I Don’t Want to Be a Mother to a Man’
description: The novelist Sheila Heti puts her diary in alphabetical order to see if she’s changed over the years.

title: Read the Nov. 18 Memo on Alternate Trump Electors
description: This memo is among the earliest known efforts to put on paper proposals for preparing alternate slates of Trump electors in Biden-won states and helped to shape a crucial strategy President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers embraced in his efforts to overturn his election loss.

description: With its desirable 19th-century rowhouses and convenient subway access, the neighborhood is both homey and worldly.

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Sprawling Winter Storm Pushes Across the U.S.
description: The storm dropped heavy snow in parts of the Midwest as forecasters warned that it could bring dangerous accumulations of ice to the South.
content: The storm dropped heavy snow in parts of the Midwest as forecasters warned that it could bring dangerous accumulations of ice to the South.

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Ashley Flowers Wants to Up the Ante of True Crime
description: The “Crime Junkie” co-host, who oversees a network of popular podcasts, has a new podcast aimed at heating up the “coldest of cases.”
content: Late last month, Ashley Flowers, 33, the producer of more than a dozen true crime podcasts, was racing between her home and her office in Indianapolis, preparing for the arrival of two babies. The first, her daughter Josie, was born Jan. 28. The second, due this week, is a new podcast she’s hosting called “The Deck.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 2, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 2, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about tax breaks driving a rush to buy property in Puerto Rico misstated the benefits for a new investor buying a primary residence in Puerto Rico under Act 60. The purchase qualifies the investor for zero capital gains tax, but not for corporate income tax relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Celebrating Ina Garten
description: Mark her birthday with a roast chicken and her recipes for puréed potatoes and charred carrots.
content: Good morning. It’s Groundhog Day, and, whether the rodent bites the mayor or flees its shadow, winter will continue until March 20, and tomorrow will dawn much like this one and much like the one that will follow. The director Harold Ramis understood this, as do many of us who’ve been weathering the pandemic from home these past 23 months. It can be tough to get motivated!
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Trump and the Peril to Democracy
description: Readers discuss new evidence about efforts to overturn the election and Donald Trump’s comments at a rally. Also: The national debt; writing by hand.
